Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Interaction of gene flow, selection and genomic architecture on the genetics of adaptation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Organisms live in complex environments that shape the genetic basis of complex physical traits in varying and unpredictable ways. Understanding the genetic basis of such traits, which can be affected by hundreds of genes, is vital to understanding how populations respond to environmental change. Species in the wild often exist in subpopulations spread across different environments, and each environment may experience different conditions. However, subpopulations can be connected because individuals travel across space and then mate with individuals in other subpopulations. Recent studies on species in the wild have shown that even though migration and gene flow occurs, populations in different environments retain their uniqueness. Scientists are interested in determining how populations retain this genetic separation. Therefore, studies of the genetic basis of particular traits may shed light on this phenomenon. This study focuses on a system where the researchers can control migration and then examine the genetic underpinnings of traits that are unique to different populations. In particular the researchers are interested in how organisms respond to a novel heat stress environment. The work will aid in the training of a graduate student and underrepresented minorities.

This study will use the model nematode Caenorhabditis remanei to (1) examine how migration interacts with selection to affect the ability of a population to adapt to a novel heat stress environment, and (2) dissect the genetic basis of heat stress resistance. This project will use experimental evolution and next generation sequencing to dissect the genetic basis of chronic heat stress resistance. By including the effects of migration of non-adapted individuals into a heat stressed environment, this study will not only find the determinants of the genetic basis of heat stress resistance, but will also directly test the hypothesis that low levels of migration increase the strength of the genetic signal underlying novel adaptations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Organisms are complex systems living in complex environments – species in the wild often exist in multiple populations spread across a multitude of environmental circumstances. These populations can be connected via migration yet still retain adaptations to their local environment. The genetic contributions of individuals from outside the local population have long been known to influence the distribution of genetic variation across the landscape, but how exactly how these influences are manifest at the molecular level are still largely unknown and are the subject of a great deal of current interest in the field.

This study investigated how reciprocal migration of non-locally adapted individuals affected adaptation to a novel, chronic heat stress environment using experimental evolution and whole genome sequencing in the model nematode Caenorhabditis remanei. Using an experimental approach allowed the influences of selection, migration on genetic change to be estimated in a rigorous and reproducible manner. All populations showed rapid adaptation to high temperatures, but migration from low-temperature treatments did significantly inhibit adaptation as expected. Instead, the ancestral, low temperature populations showed a tendency to increase heat-stress resistance, even though they had not been exposed to high-temperature circumstances. This indicates that adaptation to high temperature largely did not generate a functional cost under low temperature conditions. Most importantly, however, at the DNA sequence level, increasing levels of migration simplified the complexity of the genomic response to selection, greatly decreasing the number of sites involved while honing the resolution of the signals that remained. Despite this simplification, however, the overall response still involved changes at many dozens of sites in the genome. These results suggest an entirely new approach to understanding and identifying the genetic basis of complex traits.

This dissertation improvement grant greatly contributed to the training and intellectual development of the supported graduate student, who completed her dissertation and is now post-doctoral research associate. Project support also allowed the graduate student to mentor several undergraduate assistants in research methods and data collection, including the production of an undergraduate honors thesis based on the work supported here.
